posts.post_content:
The reason I rate this card as a 5/5 is because it can singlehandedly screw up 2 forms of first turn kills.  
One of those is the [Protean Hulk](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Protean Hulk) "turn 0" klll, which doesn't have to be turn 0 at all.  
The other one is one which I have personally felt: the [Animate Dead](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Animate Dead) + [Buried Alive](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Buried Alive) (allowed on the first turn by a pair of rituals or some other acceleration) that searches for a [Worldgorger Dragon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Worldgorger Dragon) and some other creature that would kill the opponent instantly if given infinite black mana (such as [Oona](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Oona))  
  
Decks that can kill on the turn 1 are the most dangerous there is, so a card that can stop them cold get to be 5/5 (see also, [Leyline of Sanctity](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Leyline of Sanctity))
posts.html:
The reason I rate this card as a 5/5 is because it can singlehandedly screw up 2 forms of first turn kills.
One of those is the Protean Hulk "turn 0" klll, which doesn't have to be turn 0 at all.
The other one is one which I have personally felt: the Animate Dead + Buried Alive (allowed on the first turn by a pair of rituals or some other acceleration) that searches for a Worldgorger Dragon and some other creature that would kill the opponent instantly if given infinite black mana (such as Oona)

Decks that can kill on the turn 1 are the most dangerous there is, so a card that can stop them cold get to be 5/5 (see also, Leyline of Sanctity)

posts.post_content:
Actually this isn't only way to kill an Emrakul. Read Emmy's text: When Emrakul of the Aeons Torn is put into the graveyard...
  
   
You can sac a [Nihil Spellbomb](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Nihil Spellbomb) in response to his graveyard trigger and exile him.
  
   
This just happened in an EDH game the other night. The guy casting Emrakul looked at it, then looked at the spellbomb,pulled the spellbomb out of its sleeve, ripped it in half, and replaced it.
  
   
Ironic because this is the guy who casts [End the Turn](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=End the Turn) to counter other people's Emrakuls.
  
   
   
   
Completely unrelated, Opera spellcheck says Nihil isn't a word. In its place it suggests other nihil related words along with Nichol and Unholy. O\_o

posts.post_content:
This is a **turn-0 kill** against a large section of the Legacy field.  
  
Psychatog, your game got a lot harder.  
Dredge, good bye.  
Reanimator, you're dead.  
Eggs, you're toast.  
Vengevine, nice try.  
Crucible of Worlds, you're worthless.  
et cetera, et cetera, et cetera...  
  
Over half the decks in Legacy run some sort of recursion, many depend on it.   
  
Any of those decks got you down? Stick our of these and four [Tormod's Crypt](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tormod's Crypt) into the sideboard of almost any deck. If it's black, use [Bojuka Bog](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bojuka Bog).
posts.html:

et cetera, et cetera, et cetera...

Over half the decks in Legacy run some sort of recursion, many depend on it.

Any of those decks got you down? Stick our of these and four Tormod's Crypt into the sideboard of almost any deck. If it's black, use Bojuka Bog.

posts.post_content:
This card's ability to perma-counter the absurd anti-mill cards that have sprung up of late makes me wish that I could play it in MUC-mill. I mean, I could, but I'd have to hope to get it in the opening hand. Suppose you could just sacrifice it to [Mind Over Matter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mind Over Matter) or something if it didn't work out.  
  
Until Scars of Mirrodin, this was pretty much the only card that kept mill viable in standard (unless I'm missing one), which more-or-less forced mill to at least splash black - which isn't a bad choice by any means. Thankfully for those who like to run mono-blue, Scars gave us [Nihil Spellbomb](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Nihil Spellbomb), which, while a much lesser card, at least gave the other colors graveyard hate and mill protection. Still, for decks with a dash of black, this card is absolutely brutal as a sideboard or even 2- or 3- of if you're really worried about dredge; it works great with some decks and will absolutely devastate some opponents.  
  
This could also be why Void was re... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:

Until Scars of Mirrodin, this was pretty much the only card that kept mill viable in standard (unless I'm missing one), which more-or-less forced mill to at least splash black - which isn't a bad choice by any means. Thankfully for those who like to run mono-blue, Scars gave us Nihil Spellbomb, which, while a much lesser card, at least gave the other colors graveyard hate and mill protection. Still, for decks with a dash of black, this card is absolutely brutal as a sideboard or even 2- or 3- of if you're really worried about dredge; it works great with some decks and will absolutely devastate some opponents.

This could also be why Void was re... (see all)
